Godenne Gives Speech on Transition to Adulthood
by Kirsti Levine

"Maturing
through
adolescence can be compared
metaphorically to sailing a
ship," began Dr. Ghislaine
Godenne. She proceeded to tell
the story of Bobby, a sixteen
year old boy, who sets to sail by
himself, leaving his home and
parents behind. The emotional
changes and the obstacles
which an adolescent encounters
during the transition period
were described in terms of Bobby's sea voyage.
Godenne, Director of
Psychiatry, related the various
stages of adolescence by means
of an imaginary log, kept by
Bobby on this sea voyage. Each
entry depicted a different stage
of adolescence. The details of
her story represented the major
forces throughout the adolescent years.
The boat, which represents
the adolescent's body, was the
first example. Bobby is sailing
a ship different from those he
maneuvered before. He has left
childhood and is beginning, to
physically develop into an
adolescent. It takes Bobby time
to achieve familiarity with his
boat and to acquire the skills
necessary to sail it. According
to Godenne, the wind
represents the aggressive and
libido drives which accompany
a teenager's development. The
compass metaphorically stands
for Bobby's conscience.
"When Bobby first left home
he felt a mixture of sadness,
anxiety, and excitement,"

Godenne said. She described
this sadness as resulting from a
loss of closeness between
parents and their children. The
adolescent says he wants independence, but at the same
time he enjoys his dependence
on his parents.
He is both apprehensive and
excited about what lies before
him. This anxiety is relieved to
some extent by association with
his peers. Bobby feels more
comfortable when he has
weathered the storm and his
peers (the fleet) have faired
equally. Godenne emphasizes
the importance of an adolescent
gaining support from his peers.
As strong a positive force as
peer support may be, peer
pressure can be equally
detrimental. The teenager who
stands out, who is physically
different, often has a troubled
and difficult adolescence.
Physical appearance plays a
major role in an adolescent's
development. "The teenager
strives to look exactly like his
parents," said Godenne. If he
is noticeably different from his
parents, he often suffers additional stress during this growth
period.
"During adolescence, three
stages of the libido drive occur," continued Godenne. The
first stage is that of narcissism,
or love for one's self. As the
adolescent turns away from his
parents, the first person who he
can direct his feelings toward is
himself. In the next stage, the
teenager develops a love for
and a strong friendship with so.

meone of his own sex. This is
because the adolescent sees
himself in this person. The third
and final stage is that of
heterosexual love where the
teenager has interest in developping a relation with a member
of the opposite sex.
As the voyage continues,
Bobby gains confidence in
himself and learns selfrestraint. Godenne described a
major turning point during the
adolescent years as when the
teenager recognizes that consequences do exist for his actions.

feel they've done everything

demanding, however, that the
administration create a formal
procedure for handling complaints of sexual harassment.

handling such complaints is
largely unstructured. According
to Yvonne Theodore, the
university's affirmative action
officer and the person responsible for dealing with such complaints, the complainant is invited to her office to "totally
air all concerns." Theodore
said she then contacts the accused person and his supervisor. Theodore then meets

story, and to reiterate that there
must not be any retaliation
against the complainant.
Theodore said she also stays in
contact with the complainant,
both to offer counseling and to
insure that there is no retaliation. She said that her office is
not usually involved in the
resolution of the matter, as this
often involves legal action.

Parents' Weekend
To Involve Dance
by Jim Woodruff,

This year Parents' Weekend
will be held in conjunction with
several other events, all of
which are planned to make the
freshmen orientation program
a continued and more thorough
event than in previous years. In
addition, Parent's Weekend
will be larger and will include
more events involving both
parents and freshmen than in
the past.
Andrea Perry the Director of
Residential Life, said that the
revised agenda originated from
a "commitment to extend
orientation beyond the five-day
period in September in order to
integrate freshmen with upperclassmen and the university
as a whole."
The goals of the orientation
program are: to help freshmen
in moving into the dorms and
meeting their advisors and the
president; to give the freshmen
opportunities to meet fellow
students through various activities; and last, to aid them in
finding the services and
facilities that the university
offers.
"All these things are difficult
to accomoplish in five days,"
Perry said. "We felt that it
should be a year-long effort."
Parent's Weekend will be included with the Student
Council-sponsored facultyfreshmen reception, a Friday
evening dinner in the Terrace

Room, Saturday football
festivities, and the Pretentious
Ball, which will be held in the
Glass Pavilion.
These originally separate
events will be combined with
Parent's Weekend because,
Perry said, "we wanted to include as many people as possible in these events; we've noticed in the past that many parents
do not attend Parent's
Weekend, and as a result many
kids are left out of these
happenings."
The weekend begins Friday
with the faculty-freshman
reception, which will give
parents and students a general
overview of the social and
academic aspects of the university. That evening, a "sitdown" dinner will be held,
complete with a string trio adding background music.
Saturday will begin with a
pep rally in the freshman quad
followed by the football game.
"One thing we've seen is that
this year's freshmen class has a
lot of spirit," Perry said.
"We've therefore organized a
banner contest among the
various houses."
The keynote event of the
weekend will be the Pretentious
Ball. People attending will be
encouraged to dress in gaudy,
throwback garb, and a Rolls
Royce and honor gaurd will be
ordered to lend a truly snobbish
atmosphere to the evening.

S. Blumberg Dies
After Long Illness
Stanley E. Blumberg, retired
director of Alumni Relations,
died at his home Monday morning, October 8, after a long illness. He was 68.
A memorial service has been
scheduled for Friday, Nov. 2,
at 4:30 p.m. in the Mudd Hall
Auditorium.
There will be a private family funeral. The family requests,
in lieu of flowers, contributions
to the Stanley E. Blumberg
Scholarship Fund at The Johns
Hopkins University.
"Stan Blumberg's contributions to Johns Hopkins alumni
relations were spectacular,"
University President Steven
Muller said. "He loved the
university and its alumni and
that love paid rich dividends
and was widely reciprocated. It
was my joy to travel with him
frequently and thus to be friend
as well as colleague. I mourn
his loss and. cherish his
achievements."
Blumberg became Director
of Alumni Relations in 1970
following many years as an
advertising executive in
Baltimore. In his 13 years at
Hopkins, he revolutionized the
alumni programs at the University and annual support for the
Alumni Association increased
from $50,000 to $400,000.
Evitts,
William
J.
Blumberg's successor, said, "It
is impossible to overstate what
Stan Blumberg's energy and

love of Johns Hopkins have
meant to this University. It is
equally difficult to grasp the
fact that he is gone. His death
is a staggering loss, softened
only by the wonderful legacy he
left behind in the Alumni Relations program."
Prior to assuming his
Hopkins post, Blumberg was a
vice president and account executive of the Leon Shaffer
Golnick firm and, for 19 years,
he was associated with the
Joseph Katz Company (another
advertising agency) where he
was president from 1959 to
1965.
Born in Baltimore, December
1,1915, Mr. Blumberg
graduated in 1932 from
Baltimore City College where
he received the Peabody Award
for scholastic achievement and
a one-year scholarship to
Hopkins. As a student at Johns
Hopkins, he was editor of the
News-Letter, the student paper,
and was elected to Phi Beta
Kappa. He graduated in 1935
with a B.A. in German.
During World War II,
Blumberg was a communications officer in the U.S. Naval
Reserve and served for two and
a half years with the Seventh
Fleet in the Southwest Pacific.
He is survived by his wife,
three children--Helen Blumberg
Yeager, Andrew Blumberg, and
David Blumberg--and two
grandchildren, all of Baltimore.

by Jean Schroeder
Construction of a two-level
garage on San Martin Drive has
begun. The facility, located
across from the Space
Telescope building and adjacent to the Athletic Center, will
serve only those employed in
the Space Telescope building.
According
to
Tom
McCracken, director of plant
planning, the lower level of the
new facility will function as a
parking lot with space for 78
vehicles, while the upper level
will initially house temporary
offices. After three years these
offices will be removed and the
upper level will provide an additional 72 parking spaces. Currently, there are 105 parking
spaces in a flat surface lot and
a shuttle is running from
remote parking facilities to the

McCracken explained that
the temporary offices are needed because of a "space shortage
in the Space Telescope
Building". This shortage is expected to become more severe
when the telescope is launched
due to media coverage of the
event. The launch is scheduled
for late in 1986.
It is possible that an addition
will be made on the present
Space Telescope building
before the temporary offices in
the garage are removed.
McCracken already knows the
side of the present building
where such an addition would
be made.
In order to build the new
facility, it was necessary to temporarily reduce the size of the
soccer field next to the Athletic
Center. The garage will be in

be visible from San Martin
Drive. McCracken commented
that the final size of the field
will be slightly larger than it was
previously. The scheduled completion date is July 30, 1985.
The cost of the structure is
approximately four million
dollars and it is being funded by
the university. Just as with the
Space Telescope building,
NASA will take a fifteen year
lease on the garage from the
university. At the end of this
time, the cost to the university
will be recovered.

"Dawn Ledbetter is the new
powerhouse addition to the
team," claims junior diving
captain Nancy Robbins. She is
"the best diver we've had at
Hopkins," says Coach Miles
Chedekel. Her potential is
summed up by coaches and
teammates alike as nothing less
than "tremendous."
This year's top freshman
recruit? Actually Chedkel had
never even heard of Ledbetter
before the first week of school,
when he and Robbins saw her
having some fun at the diving
pool. Eager for new team
members, they invited her to a
practice, and she has been part
of the team ever since.
That isn't the first time that
a walk-on has made a varsity
team at Hopkins, but this story
is unique because Ledbetter,
who hails from Post Falls,
Iowa, has never before dove
competitively.
"We didn't have a pool at
my high school," said the
freshman. "There wasn't a
single pool in the whole town."
Instead of chlorinated water, in
fact, Ledbetter learned to dive
in a lake near her home, over
which her father had erected a
springboard. "It was set up
right on the dock," she said.
Chedekel predicts that
Ledbetter will break all of the

Hopkins diving records if she
competes for four years, as she
is already performing at a level
of difficulty above that of
record-holders Tracey Stambaugh and Lee Ann Faulkner.

who just last month was learning the basics of competitive
diving.

year, I was learning the fundamentals of the sport, such as

of the required dives," she said.

an eardrum performing a forward twist. "Now I try and

the sport is certainly
phenomenal. Chedekel goes as
far as to say that if all goes well,
he expects her to have a shot at
the Division III Nationals, as
well as All-America honors.
Why did a high school senior
from Idaho with so much talent
decide to come to Hopkins?
"Well, it's the best school for
pre-meds,"
she
said.

The eighth annual Hopkins
Fall Golf Classic took place last
Friday with a record number of

In the individual contest,

par, to clinch the low medalist
for the day. Brett Greene of

Polo
by Erik Kreutner
The JHU water polo team,
led by junior Tito Hernandez,
finished its Middle Atlantic
Conference qualifying season
unbeaten with a three-game
sweep last weekend at
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
in Troy, New York.
The Jays defeated Queens
College in the opener, overcoming a spirited performance by
their goaltender. In the second
game, Hopkins played sluggishly, but still topped St. Francis of New York. Sunday,
Hopkins finished up in impressive style, crushing hapless
Penn State in a 17-6 rout. Hernandez scored 11 goals, 5 in the
fourth quarter, tying the .Blue
Jay single-game record set last
year.
With the three wins, Hopkins
ran their season record to
10-1-1 and 7-0 in the MAC,
clinching them second seeding
in the conference tournament,
to be held next weekend at the
Naval Academy in Annapolis.
Cornell goes into the tourney
seeded first, while Indiana U.
of Pennsylvania will be third.
These two teams are considered
to be the main roadblocks to
the Jays' championship drive.
The matches last week went
extremely well for Hopkins
considering that the polo squad
played with only two men on
the bench and without two
starters, senior Mike Hellberg
and freshman Ed Mench. Other
good performances were turned in by co-captain Wally
Wilson, hole man Kevin Anderson, who received a blow in the
eye against Penn State, but still
managed to finish the game,
and junior Wink Dyer, who
was especially impressive in the
finale. Sophomore Matt Hepler
also displayed added maturity
in coming off the bench to
score a key goal.
All Hopkins students are invited to make the trip to Annapolis to cheer on the Jays in
the MAC's next weekend,
which will be followed by the
East Coast championships at
the U. S. Military Academy at
West Point, New York,
November 9-11.

Messiah Ends Lady Jays' First Playoff Bid,5-0
.41••••-

by Howard Bregman
The Blue Jay football squad
can learn a worthwhile lesson
from the field hockey team's
miserable road trip last
weekend: don't take Dickinson
too lightly.
The Red Devils, who seek
tommorow to spoil Parent's
Weekend at Homewood for the
gridders, beat the overconfident Blue Jay hocksters,
3-1, last Saturday, and sent
them headlong into a disastrous
confrontation with Messiah
College on Monday. The
Falcons, ranked fourth nationally in Division III,
welcomed the opportunity, and
easily ended the Jays' first ever
playoff bid in the MAC with a
5-0 trouncing.
The painful part for the team
said Head Coach Sally Beth
Anderson was not the loss to
Messiah, but the fact that the
Jays were forced to face the
Falcons at all. "Everyone in the
division was trying to avoid
having to play them," said the
coach."We just fell into it."
Indeed, the Jays had their
fate in their own hands. A victory over the hapless Red
Devils, who were 3-5 going into Saturday's contest, would
have clinched the Southwest
division title and a berth in the
other bracket of the conference
tournament. In that case, the
only opportunity to meet the
Falcons, the dominant MAC
power, would have been in the
championship, a much more
exciting game in which to lose.
Instead of the Jays, 2-1-1 in
division play, the Gettysberg
Bullets, 2-0-2, captured first
place.
"We should have won," said
Anderson,"but we didn't play
at our usual level. Most of the
team went in with the attitude
that this would be an easy win,
that it wouldn't take much effort." The Blue Jays scored
first, as junior co-captain Judy
Schmidt put in a penalty stroke
at 14:51 into the first half. But
after the ice was broken, it was
all Dickinson.
The Jays' problem seemed to
be an urge to overlook the Red
Devils in preparation for the
start of the playoffs. A victory
over Western Maryland on October 12, clinched the playoff
spot, as the Terrors fell to 2-1-1
with the loss. The Jays ended
up with the same record, but
the win gave them the edge in
the divisional ranking.

After tying the Jays, 1-1, on
September 20, the Bullets
grabbed the top spot by playing
the Terrors to the same score.
All three teams earned wins
over the Juniata Indians, and
both Gettysburg and Western
Maryland had little problem
disposing of the Red Devils.
Saturday's loss, then, was
certainly a surprise to the team,
which had had met much better opponents and had come
away with convincing and often
surprising victories.
"We had expected to win
easily," said Schmidt, "but
nobody played as if they really
wanted to win. They were a
psyched-up team with nothing
to lose, and they managed to
win easily."
Hurting the Jays' effort were
a grass field and a supportive
parent's weekend crowd in
Carlisle. Though they sport a
9-4-3 record overall, the Jays
are 2-3-2 on grass. The
Homewood astroturf seems to
successfully frustrate other
teams, but it does little to help
the Jays adapt to natural and
less predictable playing
surfaces.
Hopkins led in penalty corners, 9-4, but many of the ensuing shots went wide. Dickinson also trailed in the shot
category, with eleven to
Hopkins' fifteen, but only the
Red Devils managed to make
theirs count throughout the
game. A first-half goal off a
lazy Blue Jay defense started
the Dickinson comeback.
"I was really angry after that
goal," said Anderson. "Our
whole defense seemed to let up,
and no one got back until it was
too late. We could see it coming from the sidelines. Compared to the first one, the others
didn't bother me so much."
The Red Devils scored two
more goals in the second half;
the total of three was the
highest charged to junior goalie
Amy Zimmerman since the
Drew Tournament back on
September 8.
The problem that Hopkins
has faced all season, said
Anderson, is the lack of leadership on the field that is
necessary to motivate the
players. With six freshman on
the starting squad, lack of experience is certainly another of
the Jays' troubles.

Messiah on Monday afternoon
turned out to be less of a competition and more of a lesson in

by Kirsti Levine

"Maturing
through
adolescence can be compared
metaphorically to sailing a
ship," began Dr. Ghislaine
Godenne. She proceeded to tell
the story of Bobby, a sixteen
year old boy, who sets to sail by
himself, leaving his home and
parents behind. The emotional
changes and the obstacles
which an adolescent encounters
during the transition period
were described in terms of Bobby's sea voyage.
Godenne, Director of
Psychiatry, related the various
stages of adolescence by means
of an imaginary log, kept by
Bobby on this sea voyage. Each
entry depicted a different stage
of adolescence. The details of
her story represented the major
forces throughout the adolescent years.
The boat, which represents
the adolescent's body, was the
first example. Bobby is sailing
a ship different from those he
maneuvered before. He has left
childhood and is beginning, to
physically develop into an
adolescent. It takes Bobby time
to achieve familiarity with his
boat and to acquire the skills
necessary to sail it. According
to Godenne, the wind
represents the aggressive and
libido drives which accompany
a teenager's development. The
compass metaphorically stands
for Bobby's conscience.
"When Bobby first left home
he felt a mixture of sadness,
anxiety, and excitement,"

Godenne said. She described
this sadness as resulting from a
loss of closeness between
parents and their children. The
adolescent says he wants independence, but at the same
time he enjoys his dependence
on his parents.
He is both apprehensive and
excited about what lies before
him. This anxiety is relieved to
some extent by association with
his peers. Bobby feels more
comfortable when he has
weathered the storm and his
peers (the fleet) have faired
equally. Godenne emphasizes
the importance of an adolescent
gaining support from his peers.
As strong a positive force as
peer support may be, peer
pressure can be equally
detrimental. The teenager who
stands out, who is physically
different, often has a troubled
and difficult adolescence.
Physical appearance plays a
major role in an adolescent's
development. "The teenager
strives to look exactly like his
parents," said Godenne. If he
is noticeably different from his
parents, he often suffers additional stress during this growth
period.

stages of the libido drive occur," continued Godenne. The
first stage is that of narcissism,
or love for one's self. As the
adolescent turns away from his
parents, the first person who he
can direct his feelings toward is
himself. In the next stage, the
teenager develops a love for
and a strong friendship with so.

Parents' Weekend
To Involve Dance
by Jim Woodruff,

This year Parents' Weekend
will be held in conjunction with
several other events, all of
which are planned to make the
freshmen orientation program
a continued and more thorough
event than in previous years. In
addition, Parent's Weekend
will be larger and will include
more events involving both
parents and freshmen than in
the past.
Andrea Perry the Director of
Residential Life, said that the
revised agenda originated from
a "commitment to extend
orientation beyond the five-day
period in September in order to
integrate freshmen with upperclassmen and the university
as a whole."
The goals of the orientation
program are: to help freshmen
in moving into the dorms and
meeting their advisors and the
president; to give the freshmen
opportunities to meet fellow
students through various activities; and last, to aid them in
finding the services and
facilities that the university
offers.
"All these things are difficult
to accomoplish in five days,"
Perry said. "We felt that it
should be a year-long effort."
Parent's Weekend will be included with the Student
Council-sponsored facultyfreshmen reception, a Friday
evening dinner in the Terrace

Room, Saturday football
festivities, and the Pretentious
Ball, which will be held in the
Glass Pavilion.
These originally separate
events will be combined with
Parent's Weekend because,
Perry said, "we wanted to include as many people as possible in these events; we've noticed in the past that many parents
do not attend Parent's
Weekend, and as a result many
kids are left out of these
happenings."
The weekend begins Friday
with the faculty-freshman
reception, which will give
parents and students a general
overview of the social and
academic aspects of the university. That evening, a "sitdown" dinner will be held,
complete with a string trio adding background music.
Saturday will begin with a
pep rally in the freshman quad
followed by the football game.
"One thing we've seen is that
this year's freshmen class has a
lot of spirit," Perry said.
"We've therefore organized a
banner contest among the
various houses."
The keynote event of the
weekend will be the Pretentious
Ball. People attending will be
encouraged to dress in gaudy,
throwback garb, and a Rolls
Royce and honor gaurd will be
ordered to lend a truly snobbish
atmosphere to the evening.

S. Blumberg Dies
After Long Illness
Stanley E. Blumberg, retired
director of Alumni Relations,
died at his home Monday morning, October 8, after a long illness. He was 68.
A memorial service has been
scheduled for Friday, Nov. 2,
at 4:30 p.m. in the Mudd Hall
Auditorium.
There will be a private family funeral. The family requests,
in lieu of flowers, contributions
to the Stanley E. Blumberg
Scholarship Fund at The Johns
Hopkins University.
"Stan Blumberg's contributions to Johns Hopkins alumni
relations were spectacular,"
University President Steven
Muller said. "He loved the
university and its alumni and
that love paid rich dividends
and was widely reciprocated. It
was my joy to travel with him
frequently and thus to be friend
as well as colleague. I mourn
his loss and. cherish his
achievements."
Blumberg became Director
of Alumni Relations in 1970
following many years as an
advertising executive in
Baltimore. In his 13 years at
Hopkins, he revolutionized the
alumni programs at the University and annual support for the
Alumni Association increased
from $50,000 to $400,000.
Evitts,
William
J.
Blumberg's successor, said, "It
is impossible to overstate what
Stan Blumberg's energy and

love of Johns Hopkins have
meant to this University. It is
equally difficult to grasp the
fact that he is gone. His death
is a staggering loss, softened
only by the wonderful legacy he
left behind in the Alumni Relations program."
Prior to assuming his
Hopkins post, Blumberg was a
vice president and account executive of the Leon Shaffer
Golnick firm and, for 19 years,
he was associated with the
Joseph Katz Company (another
advertising agency) where he
was president from 1959 to
1965.
Born in Baltimore, December
1,1915, Mr. Blumberg
graduated in 1932 from
Baltimore City College where
he received the Peabody Award
for scholastic achievement and
a one-year scholarship to
Hopkins. As a student at Johns
Hopkins, he was editor of the
News-Letter, the student paper,
and was elected to Phi Beta
Kappa. He graduated in 1935
with a B.A. in German.
During World War II,
Blumberg was a communications officer in the U.S. Naval
Reserve and served for two and
a half years with the Seventh
Fleet in the Southwest Pacific.
He is survived by his wife,
three children--Helen Blumberg
Yeager, Andrew Blumberg, and
David Blumberg--and two
grandchildren, all of Baltimore.

feeling our son had been spared
one of the worst forms of
cancer.
"My relief was based on ignorance. Leukemia, especially
in children, is treatable and frequently curable. Aplastic
anemia is less well-known but
much more lethal."

Aplastic anemia is the unexplained failure of bone marrow
to produce blood-clotting
platelet cells, infection-fighting
white blood cells and oxygencarrying red blood cells. The
absence of these cells causes un-

controlled bleeding, infection,
and symptoms of anemia—
fatigue, weakness, and shortness of breath.
Without treatment, aplastic
anemia is one of the most
rapidly fatal diseases known.
Even with excellent medical
care, most patients with severe
aplastic anemia generally live
only a few weeks or months.
Bone marrow transplantation, though dangerous, can
cure the disease because it
repopulates the bone marrow
with a donor's stem cells, immature cells that give rise to red
cells, white cells and platelets.
Although the disease is little
known, doctors diagnose approximately 2,000 new cases of
aplastic anemia in the U.S. each
year. The cause of these cases
is rarely discovered.

Diving competition begins
tonight in the Homewood pool
with the annual Comfort
Classic, an intersquad scrimmage. This will be the last
swimming and diving warm-up
before the MAC Relays next
Saturday.
The men's team is led by
returning two-time AllAmerican Chris Anderson. His
twelfth place finish at Nationals
on the three-meter board and
eighth place finish on the onemeter board is a "definite
asset" to the men's tournament
team, said Coach Miles
Chedekel."He is definitely diving above the level he was at
last year." Women's captain
Nancy Robbins calls her teammate a "great diver with lots of
talent."
The Jays recruited freshman
Mike Implicito as the other half
of the men's team. A nondiving related knee injury has
prevented Implicito from participating in practices. Chedekel
is still unsure whether the
freshman can return to dive for
Hopkins, as the orthopedist has
not determined whether the injury affects a ligament or
cartilage.
Along with freshman walkon Dawn Ledbetter, Robbins
and junior Mary Slagle are expected to provide the depth to
keep the women's half of the

Women's Captain Nancy Robbins Performs a pike in practice.

team on the winning track.
Chedekel asseses the two upperclassmen as "solid divers"
on whom the Jays can depend
for points at the team MAC
Championships.
Robbins led the Lady Jays
with a fifth place finish on the
three-meter board, and a
twelfth place finish on the onemeter board last year. The
junior agrees that she did "well
on the high board," and she

predicts that she and Slagle will
be throwing dives with higher
degrees of difficulty this year.
Slagle, a walk-on as a
sophomore and a former
Maryland State gymnastic

are welcome.

"Dawn Ledbetter is the new
powerhouse addition to the
team," claims junior diving
captain Nancy Robbins. She is
"the best diver we've had at
Hopkins," says Coach Miles
Chedekel. Her potential is
summed up by coaches and
teammates alike as nothing less
than "tremendous."
This year's top freshman
recruit? Actually Chedkel had
never even heard of Ledbetter
before the first week of school,
when he and Robbins saw her
having some fun at the diving
pool. Eager for new team
members, they invited her to a
practice, and she has been part
of the team ever since.
That isn't the first time that
a walk-on has made a varsity
team at Hopkins, but this story
is unique because Ledbetter,
who hails from Post Falls,
Iowa, has never before dove
competitively.
"We didn't have a pool at
my high school," said the
freshman. "There wasn't a
single pool in the whole town."
Instead of chlorinated water, in
fact, Ledbetter learned to dive
in a lake near her home, over
which her father had erected a
springboard. "It was set up
right on the dock," she said.
Chedekel predicts that
Ledbetter will break all of the

Hopkins diving records if she
competes for four years, as she
is already performing at a level
of difficulty above that of
record-holders Tracey Stambaugh and Lee Ann Faulkner.
All of this acclaim goes to a girl
who just last month was learning the basics of competitive
diving.
"In the beginning of the
year, I was learning the fundamentals of the sport, such as
the approach, the vault, and all
of the required dives," she said.
Currently, she is developing a
two and one-half somersault
off the three-meter board.
Problems arose early in the
season, as Ledbetter ruptured
an eardrum performing a forward twist. "Now I try and
stick with backward twists,"
she said. She has also had problems with fear of the higher
board, but this has been overcome gradually.
Ledbetter's proficiency is attributed to her natural abilities
fostered by years of gymnastics
training, but her adaptation to
the sport is certainly
phenomenal. Chedekel goes as
far as to say that if all goes well,
he expects her to have a shot at
the Division III Nationals, as
well as All-America honors.
Why did a high school senior
from Idaho with so much talent
decide to come to Hopkins?
"Well, it's the best school for
pre-meds,"
she
said.

The eighth annual Hopkins
Fall Golf Classic took place last
Friday with a record number of
80 competitors from 13 Universities and Colleges in the region.
The Tournament was held at
the short but tricky Mount
Pleasant Golf Course.
After 18 holes, Millersville
placed first with a combined
four-man team score of 312
strokes. University of Delaware
and LaSalle were both close
behind with scores of 316 and
317, respectively. Hopkins
turned in four solid scores of 90
and below, finishing with a
team total of 350.
In the individual contest,
Bob Mattone of Delaware carded a superb 72, only one over
par, to clinch the low medalist
for the day. Brett Greene of

Millersville was runner-up with
a 74.
The Blue Jays fielded an extraordinarily young team for
tournament:
two

back nine. Steve Schiller, who
couldn't play last year due to
adjustment difficulties, turned
in a solid 87 after only minimal
practice.

Freshman sensation Todd
Stefan was perhaps the only
disappointment of the day.
Stefan, although a bit inconsistent off the tee, was on his way
to a fine round until he reached the treacherous 15th hole.
Stefan's inexperience took its
toll as he spent half an hour on
the hole, finally chopping his
way to a nasty 10. In spite of
this, Stefan finished in 88, and
with a little practice could make
a run at the number 1 spot on

the team.
Rounding off the Blue Jay
Squad were freshmen Mark
Sullivan and Chai Kulsak,
shooting 90 and 93, respectively. The two players obviously
felt the effects of a foreign
course and lack of practice
nevertheless
but
time,

Also competing for Hopkins
on a non-scoring basis were
Mike Walutes and 7 ony Wu,
both potential st ters this

spring.

after the tournament, Coach

a very successful season this

Polo
by Erik Kreutner
The JHU water polo team,
led by junior Tito Hernandez,
finished its Middle Atlantic
Conference qualifying season
unbeaten with a three-game
sweep last weekend at
Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
in Troy, New York.
The Jays defeated Queens
College in the opener, overcoming a spirited performance by
their goaltender. In the second
game, Hopkins played sluggishly, but still topped St. Francis of New York. Sunday,
Hopkins finished up in impressive style, crushing hapless
Penn State in a 17-6 rout. Hernandez scored 11 goals, 5 in the
fourth quarter, tying the .Blue
Jay single-game record set last
year.
With the three wins, Hopkins
ran their season record to
10-1-1 and 7-0 in the MAC,
clinching them second seeding
in the conference tournament,
to be held next weekend at the
Naval Academy in Annapolis.
Cornell goes into the tourney
seeded first, while Indiana U.
of Pennsylvania will be third.
These two teams are considered
to be the main roadblocks to
the Jays' championship drive.
The matches last week went
extremely well for Hopkins
considering that the polo squad
played with only two men on
the bench and without two
starters, senior Mike Hellberg
and freshman Ed Mench. Other
good performances were turned in by co-captain Wally
Wilson, hole man Kevin Anderson, who received a blow in the
eye against Penn State, but still
managed to finish the game,
and junior Wink Dyer, who
was especially impressive in the
finale. Sophomore Matt Hepler
also displayed added maturity
in coming off the bench to
score a key goal.
All Hopkins students are invited to make the trip to Annapolis to cheer on the Jays in
the MAC's next weekend,
which will be followed by the
East Coast championships at
the U. S. Military Academy at
West Point, New York,
November 9-11.

Hocksters fall to 9-4-3

Messiah Ends Lady Jays' First Playoff Bid,5-0
.41••••-

by Howard Bregman
The Blue Jay football squad
can learn a worthwhile lesson
from the field hockey team's
miserable road trip last
weekend: don't take Dickinson
too lightly.
The Red Devils, who seek
tommorow to spoil Parent's
Weekend at Homewood for the
gridders, beat the overconfident Blue Jay hocksters,
3-1, last Saturday, and sent
them headlong into a disastrous
confrontation with Messiah
College on Monday. The
Falcons, ranked fourth nationally in Division III,
welcomed the opportunity, and
easily ended the Jays' first ever
playoff bid in the MAC with a
5-0 trouncing.
The painful part for the team
said Head Coach Sally Beth
Anderson was not the loss to
Messiah, but the fact that the
Jays were forced to face the
Falcons at all. "Everyone in the
division was trying to avoid
having to play them," said the
coach."We just fell into it."
Indeed, the Jays had their
fate in their own hands. A victory over the hapless Red
Devils, who were 3-5 going into Saturday's contest, would
have clinched the Southwest
division title and a berth in the
other bracket of the conference
tournament. In that case, the
only opportunity to meet the
Falcons, the dominant MAC
power, would have been in the
championship, a much more
exciting game in which to lose.
Instead of the Jays, 2-1-1 in
division play, the Gettysberg
Bullets, 2-0-2, captured first
place.
"We should have won," said
Anderson,"but we didn't play
at our usual level. Most of the
team went in with the attitude
that this would be an easy win,
that it wouldn't take much effort." The Blue Jays scored
first, as junior co-captain Judy
Schmidt put in a penalty stroke
at 14:51 into the first half. But
after the ice was broken, it was
all Dickinson.
The Jays' problem seemed to
be an urge to overlook the Red
Devils in preparation for the
start of the playoffs. A victory
over Western Maryland on October 12, clinched the playoff
spot, as the Terrors fell to 2-1-1
with the loss. The Jays ended
up with the same record, but
the win gave them the edge in
the divisional ranking.

After tying the Jays, 1-1, on
September 20, the Bullets
grabbed the top spot by playing
the Terrors to the same score.
All three teams earned wins
over the Juniata Indians, and
both Gettysburg and Western
Maryland had little problem
disposing of the Red Devils.
Saturday's loss, then, was
certainly a surprise to the team,
which had had met much better opponents and had come
away with convincing and often
surprising victories.
"We had expected to win
easily," said Schmidt, "but
nobody played as if they really
wanted to win. They were a
psyched-up team with nothing
to lose, and they managed to
win easily."
Hurting the Jays' effort were
a grass field and a supportive
parent's weekend crowd in
Carlisle. Though they sport a
9-4-3 record overall, the Jays
are 2-3-2 on grass. The
Homewood astroturf seems to
successfully frustrate other
teams, but it does little to help
the Jays adapt to natural and
less predictable playing
surfaces.
Hopkins led in penalty corners, 9-4, but many of the ensuing shots went wide. Dickinson also trailed in the shot
category, with eleven to
Hopkins' fifteen, but only the
Red Devils managed to make
theirs count throughout the
game. A first-half goal off a
lazy Blue Jay defense started
the Dickinson comeback.
"I was really angry after that
goal," said Anderson. "Our
whole defense seemed to let up,
and no one got back until it was
too late. We could see it coming from the sidelines. Compared to the first one, the others
didn't bother me so much."
The Red Devils scored two
more goals in the second half;
the total of three was the
highest charged to junior goalie
Amy Zimmerman since the
Drew Tournament back on
September 8.
The problem that Hopkins
has faced all season, said
Anderson, is the lack of leadership on the field that is
necessary to motivate the
players. With six freshman on
the starting squad, lack of experience is certainly another of
the Jays' troubles.
The confrontation with
Messiah on Monday afternoon
turned out to be less of a competition and more of a lesson in

Frostburg State at first and second, and Mt. St. Mary's and
Western Maryland at fourth
and fifth, respectively.
Hopkins defeated Salisbury
last year in an upset, and lost
in the tournament finals to
Frostburg in a flick-off. The
Gulls will be the Jays' first opponents tomorrow afternoon.

*A full copy of the above newsletter was found in a student's mailbox and brought to the attention
of the women's community. To make the campus and the community aware of the offensive sexual
attitudes which pervade Johns Hopkins we felt it necessary to publicize the original newsletter. We contacted the University's Deans with a letter signed by many supporters including faculty, students and
staff stating that"...it is intolerable that such explicit degradation of women is associated with the
Johns Hopkins University." Because the Fraternities recieve their charter from the University, the Fraternities must abide by the University's Sexual Harassment Policy.
•TEP did issue an apology to the M. "We are extremely embarrassed that such material as appeared
Carey Thomas Women's Center:
in the recent TEP newsletter was displayed to the Johns Hopkins
community...it is unfair that this publication threatened women,
and their reaction is completely understandable."
TEP assured the Women's Center that the views expressed in
the newsletter were not those held by the entire fraternity and
that they have taken action to insure that this will not happen
again.
*Although this issue was raised by the actions of one individual, we feel that it is indicative of attitudes
and behavior underlying the community at large.
*We demand:

1.that the University take responsibility to enforce its own
policies and issue a statement defining the application of the
Sexual Harassment Policy.
2.that a General Grievance Procedure be adopted, composed
of all sectors of the university, staff, faculty, administration,
and graduate and undergraduate students.
3.that there be an administration and student sponsored Sexual harassment education forum available for the community.
4.that the Inter-Fraternity Council add the following amendment to the IFC Constitution:
The Inter-Fraternity Council shall take the responsibility of upholding the JHU Sexual Harassment
Policy...(and) shall investigate any charges of violation
of this policy according to the procedures in the Grievance
Board by-laws.

*Monday, October 22, 250 graduate and undergraduate students from both Goucher and Hopkins
assembled for an ad hoc meeting. They expressed overwhelming support for the actions already taken,
recognized that sexual harassment is a pervasive problem at Hopkins, and agreed that the University
has not been effective in countering this problem.
*Please show your support by writing letters to the Associate Dean of Students, Chris Columbo, or
by contacting the M. Carey Thomas Women's Center.
